items.content_html:
Description of changes

Apply a patch for CVE-2023-29383. See shadow-maint/shadow#687 and shadow-maint/shadow#695.

Things done

    • x86_64-linux
    • aarch64-linux
    • x86_64-darwin

    • NixOS test(s) (look inside nixos/tests)
    • and/or package tests
    • or, for functions and "core" functionality, tests in lib/tests or pkgs/test

  • Tested compilation of all packages that depend on this change using nix-shell -p nixpkgs-review --run "nixpkgs-review rev HEAD". Note: all changes have to be committed, also see nixpkgs-review usage
  • Tested basic functionality of all binary files (usually in ./result/bin/)
  • 23.05 Release Notes (or backporting 22.11 Release notes)

    • (Module updates) Added a release notes entry if the change is significant
    • (Module addition) Added a release notes entry if adding a new NixOS module
  • Fits CONTRIBUTING.md.

items.title: chore(flake): Automatic flake update

items.content_html:
This allows for users to build nix docker images tuned for their substituters, ca and custom packages.

For example, I would use it this way:

{ nixpkgs }:

let
  nixRepo = ./nix;
  # nixRepo = builtins.fetchTarball { ... };
  proxyChannelURL = "https://github.proxy/channel-nixos-21.11.tar.gz";
  substituterURL = "https://nixos-cache.proxy";
  myCa = ./ca.crt;
in 
(import (nixRepo + "/docker.nix") {
  pkgs = nixpkgs;
  channelURL = proxyChannelURL;
  extraPkgs = [ nixpkgs.nixops ];
  extraEnv = [
    "SSL_CERT_FILE=${myCa}"
    "GIT_SSL_CAINFO=${myCa}"
    "NIX_SSL_CERT_FILE=${myCa}"
  ];
  substituters = [ substituterURL ];
  trustedSubstituters = [ substituterURL ];
})
items.title: docker: more params: extraPkgs, (trusted)Substituters and extraEnv

items.content_html:
Motivation

Adds simple Python bindings for Nix evaluation, initialized from @Mic92's archived Pythonix (including the license), but then updated to work with the latest Nix version. This relates to #7271

Just like the existing Perl bindings under pkgs.nix.perl-bindings, these Python bindings are available as a separate derivation under pkgs.nix.python-bindings. This is a Python package that can be used as python.withPackages (p: [ pkgs.nix.python-bindings ]

The API currently is just a single function:

  • nix.eval(str, vars: dict)
    Evaluates the Nix expression str with variables vars in scope. vars is transparently converted from Python values to Nix values. The result of this function is transparently converted from a Nix value to a Python value.

An example:

flake.nix 
{
  inputs.nix.url = "github:tweag/nix/python-bindings";
  inputs.nixpkgs.follows = "nix/nixpkgs";
  inputs.flake-utils.url = "github:numtide/flake-utils";

  outputs = { nix, nixpkgs, flake-utils, ... }: flake-utils.lib.eachDefaultSystem (system: {
    defaultPackage = nixpkgs.legacyPackages.${system}.pkgs.python3.withPackages (p: [
      nix.packages.${system}.nix.python-bindings
    ]);
  });
}
$ nix run
Python 3.10.8 (main, Oct 11 2022, 11:35:05) [GCC 11.3.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import nix
>>> nix.eval("1 + a", vars=dict(a = 2))
3

This work is sponsored by Antithesis ✨

TODO

  • Confirm that the Pythonix source code can be used: #7735 (comment)
  • Make the build work, both incrementally for development and in CI
  • Mark as experimental (decided by the Nix Team)
  • Write more tests
  • Write documentation
    • How to develop the bindings
    • Manual page for how to use the bindings

Context

The motivation for this is better tests for library functions in nixpkgs. Previous efforts:

  • Using bats: NixOS/nixpkgs#185022
  • Using awk for generating property tests: NixOS/nixpkgs#205190, NixOS/nixpkgs#209099 (comment) and NixOS/nixpkgs#212858

In particular NixOS/nixpkgs#212858 highlighted that property tests are currently either slow (if using the Nix CLI) or limited (if you work around this by cramming everything into a single Nix CLI call, which then means you can't test error messages anymore).

I then instead focused on Pythonix, third-party Python bindings for the Nix evaluator. By using Python for testing we can use the Python ecosystem (such as property testing using Hypothesis), and by it linking to the Nix library it's much faster and we can test error messages too. Unfortunately Pythonix was archived due to being too hard to maintain, since the library interface isn't stable. So the fix is to just upstream it instead.

Checklist for maintainers

Maintainers: tick if completed or explain if not relevant

  • agreed on idea
  • agreed on implementation strategy
  • tests, as appropriate
    • functional tests - tests/**.sh
    • unit tests - src/*/tests
    • integration tests - tests/nixos/*
  • documentation in the manual
  • code and comments are self-explanatory
  • commit message explains why the change was made
  • new feature or bug fix: updated release notes
items.title: Experimental python bindings

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Add a security.loginDefs.settings option for the login.defs file to provide enhanced configuration abilities.

E.g. add hardening options to login.defs file

security.loginDefs.settings.ENCRYPT_METHOD = "SHA512";
security.loginDefs.settings.SHA_CRYPT_MIN_ROUNDS = 999999999;
security.loginDefs.settings.SHA_CRYPT_MAX_ROUNDS =  999999999;
security.loginDefs.settings.PASS_MAX_DAYS = 365;
security.loginDefs.settings.PASS_MIN_DAYS = 1;

items.title: nixos/shadow: refactor login.defs config options

items.content_html:
Description of changes

There's no reason to use a bootloader when testing kexec, this is a feature that reboots directly in the kernel, if anything, we should just direct boot the kernel and reboots in the kernel.

A bootloader test really makes sense to test "default" systemctl kexec behavior which is already broken because systemctl kexec will read the ESP to determine what to kexec by default.

It still fails because there is no proper reconnection in the second part of the test, though. Please maintainers take a look. I'm doing that now. :P

This can unfortunately be related to a shadow mounting of the Nix store, in which case, some fixes are around in my PRs.

Things done

items.content_html:
add darkmode images for the nixos live cd boot splash
to make the boot process consistent with the BIOS splash, which is always in darkmode

the PNG images are used in
https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/nixos/modules/installer/cd-dvd/iso-image.nix#L554

isoImage.efiSplashImage = bootloader/efi-background.png
isoImage.splashImage = bootloader/isolinux/bios-boot.png

the SVG files are simplified versions of the original inkscape SVG files
the PNG files are rendered with inkscape
items.title: Add darkmode splash images

items.content_html:
Persists user credentials.

Take note of the issue with using passwd which is explained in this thread NixOS/nixpkgs#3192

It appears that a solution is to use passwd with --root to chroot into the correct directory. (this is mentioned in the description for this option).

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Once your computer is stolen or physically accessed, you might not care about your login password being brute-forced. Unless it is also used to encrypt your key for ecryptfs/fscrypt/or other similar home directory encryption, then you really care.

This change makes the hashing algorithm used for password encoding configurable as a NixOS module option and suggests yescrypt for cases which need good brute-force resistance.

items.content_html:
Okay I never touch this package before, hopefully I am not breaking stuff.

https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/accountsservice/accountsservice/-/compare/22.08.8...23.13.9

Or the patched accountsservice: https://github.com/bobby285271/accountsservice/compare/22.08.8-patched..23.13.9-patched-unreviewed

Commits prefixed with tests

I don't think we run tests right now.

  • tests: fix the signature for the SetLocked call
  • tests: fix invocation of AddUser
  • tests: Pass a correctly-formatted locale in tests
  • tests: Add tests for new locale verification meson.build
  • tests: Add sufficient data to allow the daemon to run
  • tests: Add simple daemon test meson.build
  • tests: Add test for getting user data
  • tests: Add test for another invalid locale
  • tests: Add polkit support
  • tests: Add test for setting invalid language
  • tests: Set locale from simple daemon test
  • tests: Add library tests for "Languages" property
  • tests: Add daemon tests for new Languages property
  • tests: Add test for GetUsersLanguages() method
  • tests: Support multiple users for user data
  • tests: Add second user to test data
  • tests: Fix tests for 2nd user
  • tests: Fix dbusmock accountservice template user parameterization
  • tests: Add test for multiple in-flight get_user calls

Commits prefixed with ci

Some of them also touches tests.

  • ci: Hide CI_JOB_JWT
  • ci: Expose logs for the build too
  • ci: Install git so the version script actually works
  • ci: Run tests as a normal user
  • ci: Fail tests when some are skipped
  • ci: Run test suite under valgrind
  • ci: Make sure all locales are installed
  • ci: Fail run-tests if something fails
  • ci: Only run ci stuff on merge requests
  • ci: Do a coding style check meson.build
  • CI: Install systemd, for /usr/share/pkgconfig/systemd.pc
  • CI: Fix build in a fork whose name is not accountsservice
  • CI: Pass --gcov-ignore-parse-errors to gcovr

Translations

  • Update hr.po
  • Update Catalan translation
  • Update Hungarian translation
  • Update Hindi (hi) translation
  • po: Update Georgian translation
  • Update friulian translation
  • Update POTFILES.in

Non-trivial commits

  • daemon: Reload users less aggressively on wtmp changes
  • util: Drop spawn_with_login_uid function
  • user: Fix API docs to use neutral gender
  • data: Fix possessives
  • util: Add XPG locale verification function
  • util: Add locale verification function
  • user: Return an error when setting invalid language
  • user: Throw a warning for invalid locales
  • build: Fix warning about run_command() usage meson.build
  • all: Use pragma once
  • user-classify: Remove unused password hash argument
  • README: Remove outdated INSTALL file
  • build: Fix cwd != srcdir in generate-version.sh
  • build: Add mocklibc subproject meson.build
  • user: Add helper to allow overriding the root directory meson.build
  • main: Use new overridable USERDIR
  • main: Use new overridable ICONDIR
  • main: Use new overridable sysconfdir
  • user: Add "Languages" user property
    • Currently handle user_set_languages the same way as user_set_language
  • daemon: Move uid variable where it's used
  • daemon: Add GetUsersLanguages() function
  • src: Run entire tree through uncrustify
    • Treewide format
  • user: Replace usermod -p with chpasswd -e
    • Oh hardcoded absolute path
    • CVE-2012-6655
  • daemon: Clarify use of generator_state->users
  • daemon: Define local users as being exactly those present in /etc/shadow
  • user: Use correct format strings to print accounts_user_get_uid()
  • Annotate varargs functions with G_GNUC_PRINTF
  • daemon: Don't crash if /etc/shadow doesn't exist
  • Add lightdm autologin support meson.build
    • Not sure if anything needs to be done here
  • meson.build: fix -Wimplicit-function-declaration in configure tests for printf meson.build
  • daemon: Track local users outside of fgetpwent generator
  • user: Support new LocalAccount property in cache file 23.11.69
  • subprojects: Add mocklibc to package cache
  • daemon: Fix boot delay
  • user-manager: Don't prematurely free duplicate ActUser objects
  • user-manager: Add cancellable to fetch user requests
  • user-manager: Cope with buggy callers better
  • user-manager: Deduplicate ActUser objects when possible
  • user-manager: Track non-existent users 23.13.9

items.title: accountsservice: 22.08.8 → 23.13.9

items.content_html:
Description of changes

The plan is to go through the onboarding flow using selenium, to make sure
that the default experience, when enabling home-assistant on NixOS, is working
correctly.

It is also a stepping stone towards getting a longlived API token, with which we
could do further tests, e.g. using hass-cli.

The two packages pyshadow and webdriver-manager are leftovers from a
previous try to interact with shadow doms.

Steps:

  • user
  • core config
    • saving causes an alert() window, error is undefined
  • telemetry
    • can be skipped w/o any additional interaction
  • integration
Things done
  • Built on platform(s)
    • x86_64-linux
    • aarch64-linux
    • x86_64-darwin
    • aarch64-darwin
  • For non-Linux: Is sandbox = true set in nix.conf? (See Nix manual)
  • Tested, as applicable:
    • NixOS test(s) (look inside nixos/tests)
    • and/or package tests
    • or, for functions and "core" functionality, tests in lib/tests or pkgs/test
    • made sure NixOS tests are linked to the relevant packages
  • Tested compilation of all packages that depend on this change using nix-shell -p nixpkgs-review --run "nixpkgs-review rev HEAD". Note: all changes have to be committed, also see nixpkgs-review usage
  • Tested basic functionality of all binary files (usually in ./result/bin/)
  • 23.05 Release Notes (or backporting 22.11 Release notes)
    • (Package updates) Added a release notes entry if the change is major or breaking
    • (Module updates) Added a release notes entry if the change is significant
    • (Module addition) Added a release notes entry if adding a new NixOS module
  • Fits CONTRIBUTING.md.
items.title: nixos/tests/home-assistant: Test onboarding flow

items.content_html:
Hello there.

First off, thanks for the project! I just discovered it and I'm in the phase of getting familiar.

I ran into an issue, though, when following the GTK install instructions (from the README) for the nix-shell.

TLDR

running the following the GTK et al. installation completed successfully:

nix-shell -p '<nixpkgs>' gtk4 pkgs.gtk3 gobjectIntrospection pkgconfig



Not quite in-depth but more elaborate description

As mentioned above, the GTK install instructions from README for the nix-shell didn't work for me.
They appear to be out of date, so I went ahead and fixed them.
In fact I just followed what nix-shell told me to do and that did end up working.

the change/fix as hinted by the nix-shell

-nix-shell -p '<nixpkgs>' gtk4 gnome3.gtk gobjectIntrospection pkgconfig
+nix-shell -p '<nixpkgs>' gtk4 pkgs.gtk3 gobjectIntrospection pkgconfig
Output from the original command, which failed:
~
 ➜  nix-shell -p '<nixpkgs>' gtk4 gnome3.gtk gobjectIntrospection pkgconfig
error: The ‘gnome.gtk’ alias was removed on 2022-01-13. Please use ‘pkgs.gtk3’ directly.
(use '--show-trace' to show detailed location information)

~
 (╯°□°）╯︵ ┻━┻ 1 🔥

pic (it did happen):

Output from the fixed command:
~
 (╯°□°）╯︵ ┻━┻ 1 🔥 nix-shell -p '<nixpkgs>' gtk4 pkgs.gtk3 gobjectIntrospection pkgconfig these 334 paths will be fetched (275.79 MiB download, 1187.41 MiB unpacked):
  /nix/store/043lz8mvyx5vxl058c1i586yqc8ax4ig-glibc-2.33-108-bin
  /nix/store/04yj0nllw5bqzzlay5m6zzbmyw7csgnk-glu-9.0.2
  /nix/store/06zvvrv13xrmjqkcwyh5x9yxvgx4hvqz-libseccomp-2.5.3-lib

...
... hundreds of lines later
...

copying path '/nix/store/h8k91x18zynw58yc0k34wv5i2k0jfijx-gtk4-4.6.0' from 'https://cache.nixos.org'...
copying path '/nix/store/apgij5a7rsa8d0j5zxdl2ji3vr8kji5g-gtk4-4.6.0-dev' from 'https://cache.nixos.org'...

~ via ❄️  impure (shell)
 ➜  gtk4-<TAB><TAB>
gtk4-broadwayd            gtk4-demo-application     gtk4-launch               gtk4-update-icon-cache
gtk4-builder-tool         gtk4-encode-symbolic-svg  gtk4-print-editor         gtk4-widget-factory
gtk4-demo                 gtk4-icon-browser         gtk4-query-settings

~ via ❄️  impure (shell)
 ➜  which gtk4-demo
/nix/store/apgij5a7rsa8d0j5zxdl2ji3vr8kji5g-gtk4-4.6.0-dev/bin/gtk4-demo

pic (this also did happen):

Hope this is OK.

Cheers!
items.title: readme: fix nix-shell installation instructions

items.content_html:
We need root permission to drop supplementary groups, and if we don't do that, some builds can fail in user namespace, most notably go.

Related: #3245
items.title: Warn when building without nix daemon

items.content_html:
Description of changes

fuse consists of the library and SUID binaries. They serve different scenarios. Packages depending on libfuse don't want to pull in binaries which shadow SUID ones like fusermount and cause troubles.

With outputs splitted, we can use fuse.dev in development environment without risking shadowing SUID binaries.

Things done

Tested my FUSE projects with new fuse and fuse3.

items.title: fuse: split outputs and clean up

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Currently many Julia packages installed with the native package manager Pkg fail to work. In this PR we fix this by

  1. Adding a Julia build system to patch the binary blobs and make them available in nixpkgs with the help of the withPackages passthru attribute. A utility julia2nix is also added to facilitate adding packages to nixpkgs.
  2. Put the julia compiler in a buildFHSUserEnv thereby providing the interpreter in the expected location and defining some required environment variables.

items.title: [RFC 0110] Add "inherit-as-list" syntax construct to the Nix language

items.content_html:
Motivation for this change

makeScope breaks splicing thus makes cross compilation hard in package sets like gnome, by switching to makeScopeWithSplicing, the situation can be dramatically improved.

items.title: gnome: switch to makeScopeWithSplicing

items.content_html:
Description of changes

This PR explores supporting the new finalAttrs derivation style for buildRustPackage, similar to what is suggested in #119942 (comment). It is basically an extended version of #179392, and in particular also would close #107070.

A few notes:

  • This change should be entirely opt-in and cause no rebuilds.

  • This PR adds an ad-hoc way to prevent some attrs (called "intermediate args" here) to be passed to the underlying derivation call by specifying removeFromBuilderEnv. Another option would be to allow an arbitrary function (similar to apply in the module system), but that might be too powerful/confusing. Also see #194475 (comment).

  • Rust packages can be incrementally converted and then enjoy the benefits outlined in #119942

    As an example, I converted difftastic to the new style, such that changing its version is now much DRYer:

    pkgs.difftastic.overrideAttrs (oldAttrs: {
  version = "0.37.0";
  src = oldAttrs.src.overrideAttrs (_: {
    outputHash = "sha256-LwDoIvhZj/1fHg2eWgadwTcegeOKPpY8aCAugLfKtDE=";
  });
  cargoHash = "sha256-j7PVzGCButQhxVXVrtWhT6a6F1SLNe0jAy8oGqr9NvQ=";
  cargoLock = null;
  postPatch = "";
})

    Also note that passthru.tests.version then automatically points to the new package.

  • The "overlay" in buildRustPackage has a few curiosities, i.e. we have to be careful to avoid infinite recursion errors:

    • It is not possible to use the { a ? "", ...}@finalAttrs syntax. Even {...}@finalAttrs causes infinite recursion.
    • Asserts involving attributes from finalAttrs have to be "hidden" inside of values. Right now, I moved them to the respective attributes/variables; another option would be to put them into a dedicated asserts attribute, i.e. asserts = assert (all asserts here); "";.

    Maybe there are better solutions for these problems around, but they don't seem too terrible.

items.title: rustPlatform.buildRustPackage: support `finalAttrs` style

items.content_html:
When cross-compiling a rust package, all we need is the std library compiled
for the target. This uses the final stage compiler which was built for Build
and then uses that as a stage0 compiler for target std library.

It also copies the rust binary from pkgsBuildBuild so that it find the new
lib/rustlib directory.

We also need to create a cargo wrapper which will use the "new" rust compiler

Description of changes
